The Special Court of Appeals is not a Supreme Court of Appeals, but belongs to the class of Superior Courts provided for in the constitution of Virginia. For many years the number of causes pending in the Supreme Court of Appeals at Richmond had continued to increase, so that in the winter of 1847-8 they amounted to five hundred and sixty-four; and except such cases as were entitled to precedence, the delay in the decision of a cause in the Court was about eight years. The number of cases decided annually was scarce equal to the appeals allowed; and there was, therefore, no hope that under the then existing system the evil of the delay of justice would ever be relieved. *519For years schemes to remedy the evil had been proposed, but no one of them had sufficiently commended itself to the judgment of the General Assembly to be adopted by that body, until in the winter of 1847-8, Messrs. John M. Patton and Conway Robinson, who had been appointed to revise the statutes of Virginia, submitted to the Legislature a bill, which resulted in the act of the 31st of March 1848, entitled “An act concerning the jurisdiction of the General Court, and diminishing the number of the Judges thereof.” The first section of that act repealed the previous law, which prescribed the manner and terms of holding the General Court. The remainder of the act is as follows: “2. The five Judges of the Circuit Superior Courts who, for the time being, shall stand first in commission with respect to precedence and seniority, shall hereafter hold the sessions of the General Court. The same five Judges shall likewise constitute a Special Court of Appeals, to be holden at the City of Richmond. “ 3. Such Special Court shall annually commence its session at the State courthouse in December, on the day after the General Court adjourns, unless such adjournment be on Saturday, in which case the said Special Court shall commence the Monday following. It may adjourn from time to time, and may sit as often and as long as the Judges thereof may consider they can properly sit, without interfering with their duties as Judges of the General Court and of the Circuit Superior Courts. But there shall be no such session at Richmond, while the Court of Appeals is in session at Lewisburg. “ 4. The clerk of the Court of Appeals at Richmond shall annually in December, before such Special Court commences its session, make out a docket of all causes which on the day for such commencement shall have been depending in the Court of Appeals more than two years without being heard, unless the number of such causes ready for hearing exceed seventy, in which case *520the said clerk shall make out a docket of the seventy-causes ready for hearing, which shall have been longest pending in said Court. Aud such Special Court shall proceed to hear and determine all causes on the docket so made out: Provided hoxoever, That no case shall be placed upon said docket, where any party, by himself or his counsel, shall object thereto. “ 5. After such Special Court commences its session in December, the Court of Appeals at Richmond, shall proceed during the winter and spring to hear and determine such of the causes depending therein as may not be on the docket made out under the preceding section. In the interval between the time at which the Court of. Appeals at Richmond may commence its session in the fall, and the time at which such Special Court may commence its session in December, the said Court of Appeals at Richmond may hear and determine any cause which may remain depending therein, notwithstanding it may have been on the docket so made out under the preceding section. “ 6. If a majority of the Judges of such Special Court be interested in, or from sickness or other reason unable to hear and determine a case on the docket so made out, the said Court shall order the fact to be entered of record and the case to be struck from its docket, and thereafter the Court of Appeals may hear and determine such case. “7. If a majority of the Judges of the Court of Appeals be interested in, or from sickness or other reason unable to hear and determine a case so struck from the docket of the Special Court., or a case depending in the Court of Appeals at Lewisburg or at Richmond, that fact shall be entered of record, and certified to the Special Court of Appeals at Richmond, which shall appoint from among the Judges of said Special Court, so many as, together with the Judges of the Court of Appeals, not so interested or unable, will make the number not *521less than three, nor more than five; and they shall together hold a Special Court of Appeals for hearing and determining such case, at such time as a majority thereof may see fit. The place of holding the same shall be Richmond or Lewisburg, according as the case may be depending at the one place or the other: Provided, That if there be not as many as three Judges of the Court of Appeals, and of the Special Court of Appeals, able to sit in any case, a Special Court of Appeals for the trial thereof shall be appointed in the manner now prescribed by law. “ 8. The clerk of the Court of Appeals at the place at which any such Special Court is held, shall, in person or by deputy, attend such Special Court with the records and papers in the cases which it is to hear and determine, and enter the proceedings of such Special Court, which shall be signed by the presiding Judge thereof. The decisions of such Special Court shall be certified and carried into execution in like manner as if made by the Court of Appeals. And the clerk may, for his services, charge to parties like fees as if the proceedings were had in the Court of Appeals. “ 9. The General Court or a Special Court of Appeals may be holden by any three or more of the Judges thereof. “ 10. Each of the said five Judges of the General Court shall, in addition to his annual salary, receive 10 dollars per day for each day’s attendance on such Special Court or General Court, and be paid mileage for travel to and from the place of session, at the same rate as for other necessary travel. Such Special Court may appoint a crier and tipstaff, and allow them a reasonable compensation. “ 11. It shall not be the duty of the reporter of the Court of Appeals to report any causes decided by such Special Court, but the said Special Court may allow any *522person approved by it to report its decisions, provided it be done free of expense to the State. “ 12. This act shall be in force from its passage.” 'When this act went into operation, the five senior JU(^Ses °f the Circuit Superior Courts, were Daniel Smith, Richard H. Field, John T. Lomax, William Leigh and John Scott, Esquires. Of these, the four first named appeared at the State courthouse on the 13th of December 1848, and constituted the Special Court of Appeals, and proceeded to appoint the officers of the Court provided for by the law. On the next day, it having been suggested that the attention of the bar had not been called to the provision of the law directing the mode of making out the docket of the Court, an order was made, that on the 21st day of the month, the Court would call the docket to ascertain whether there was on it any case which any party, by himself or his counsel, objected to being thereon, and to hear any reason which might be assigned for the objection not being sooner made; and would then decide which of the causes on the docket so called, the Court would and which it would not proceed to hear and determine. In pursuance of this order, the Court did proceed on the 21st to call the docket to ascertain whether there was upon it any case which any party, by himself or his counsel, objected to being on it; and there being no case on the docket which any party objected to being there, except the two cases of Griffin's adm'r v. Macauly's adm'r, and sufficient reason being assigned in these two cases for the objection not being sooner made, the Court determined that it would proceed to hear and determine all the causes on the docket, except the said two cases; and that it would leave them to be heard by the Supreme Court of Appeals. Among the causes placed upon the docket of the Special Court of Appeals was the case of Jesse F. Keesee, adm’r of Thomas C. Keesee, deceased, and others, *523against Henry Sharpe. This was an appeal from a decree pronounced by the Superior Court of Chancery for the Richmond circuit. The cause came on to be heard in the Special Court of Appeals on the 20th of January 1849, when that Court affirmed the principles of the decree of the Chancery Court, but reversed it as to some matters of detail, and the cause was remanded to the Chancery Court. On the 9th of February 1849, Henry Sharpe produced to the Superior Court of Chancery for the Richmond circuit, a certified copy of the decree of the Special Court of Appeals, and thereupon moved that the said decree be entered of record in the Court for such proceedings to be had thereupon as are thereby directed; and he then exhibited to the Court certified copies of the orders of the Special Court hereinbefore mentioned. Whereupon the cause being docketed by consent to be heard upon the motion, came on by like consent to be heard thereupon; and the Court having seen and inspected the said decree of the Special Court of Appeals, and the exhibits filed therewith by the plaintiff, overruled the motion, and refused to enter the decree. There being some doubt whether the Supreme Court of Appeals had authority to issue a mandamus to enforce obedience by the Chancery Court to the decree of the Special Court, the General Assembly, on the 7th of February 1849, enacted, That hereafter it shall be lawful for the Supreme Court of Appeals to issue writs of mandamus to the Circuit Courts in cases both at law and in chancery, whenever such writs shall be necessary or proper to enforce obedience to the decrees and judgments of the said Court of Appeals, and in all other cases in which it may be necessary to prevent a failure of justice, in which a mandamus may issue according to the principles of the common law, — the practice and proceedings upon such writs to be governed and regulated in all cases, by the principles and practice now prevailing in respect to writs of mandamus. *524Sharpe then applied to this Court by petition for a mandamus to the Judge of the Superior Court of Chan-eery for the Richmond circuit, to compel him to enter the decree upon the records of his Court, and to observe an<^ execute th® same; and this Court accordingly, on the 10th of February 1849, made an order, that John Robertson, Esquire, Judge of the Superior Court of Chancery for the Richmond circuit, having reasonable notice of this order, do appear here on Tuesday next and shew cause, if any he can, why the Commonwealth’s writ of mandamus should not be awarded the said petitioner to command the said Judge to enter upon his records, and observe and execute a decree pronounced by the Special Court of Appeals on the 20th day of January last, in a cause between Jesse F. Keesee, adm’r of Thomas C. Keesee, appellant, and the said Henry Sharpe, appellee, which hath been duly certified by the said Special Court of Appeals to the said Superior Court of Chancery for the Richmond circuit. To this rule Judge Robertson made the following return : “ The Judge of this Court, presuming that no answer or return to the said rule was contemplated, or would be proper, in any other manner than through the medium of an entry in the order boob of his own Court, for cause why a mandamus should not be awarded, commanding him to enter upon record, and observe and execute the decree in the rule mentioned, respectfully sheweth, that the said decree was pronounced by a Court having, in the opinion of the Judge of this Court, no lawful authority or jurisdiction. “ And for further explanation, the Court of Appeals is respectfully referred to the reasons assigned by the Judge of this Court, on declining to enter the said decree, a copy of which will be transmitted herewith as a part of this return, which is ordered to be certified to the Court of Appeals.

*525“ The said opinion is in the words and figures following, to wit:

“ I hold that in this Commonwealth, there can be but one Supreme Court of Appeals.

“ The terms of the constitution conferring power to create that Court are tantamount to the most explicit negation of power to create two or more such Courts.

“ And the reason of the prohibition is as obvious as the prohibition itself is certain. The concentration of the supreme judicial power in a single Court, was doubtless regarded as necessary to the symmetry of the system as a whole, and the best means of insuring stability and uniformity of decision in all its branches.

“If the tribunal, then, established by the act of 31st March 1848, be in effect an additional Supreme Court of Appeals, none probably will deny its absolute nullity.

“ Is it such a court ?

“A careful examination has led me to the firm persuasion that it is.

“ To test the correctness of this conclusion, let us compare it with the Court of Appeals heretofore established in conformity with the constitution.

“ Each Court consists of the same number of Judges ; is attended by the same clerk ; has the same power to appoint other officers, including a reporter; has stated terms, running through a large portion of the year, and is equally unlimited in duration.

“ The jurisdiction may be said to be the same — the new Court taking cognizance, exclusively for the present, of a part of the identical causes actually pending in the Court of Appeals ; and the decisions of each are equally conclusive and irreversible.

“In its design, then, its powers, its functions; in a word, in all its essential features, the new Court seems to be, so far as an act of Assembly can impress that character, but a second co-ordinate Supreme Court.

*526“ Nor do the particulars in which it differs from the constitutional Court, seem of a nature to divest it of this objectionable and unlawful character.

u onjy p0fnts 0f difference I have been able to discover worthy of notice, relate to—

“The appointment and compensation of the Judges.

“The stability or duration of the Courts themselves.

“ And the mode of acquiring and exercising their jurisdiction.

“ 1 and 2. The appointment and compensation of Judges. It is true that the Judges of the constitutional Court were duly elected and commissioned as such, hold their offices during good behaviour, and receive, a.s the constitution requires, fixed salaries; whereas the new Court consists of Judges merely assigned to it by the act creating it, liable to lose their offices and pay as Judges of that Court, by a legislative abolition of the Court itself, and compensated by a per diem allowance.

“I do not pause to enquire whether this legislative designation, or per diem recompense, be or be not in accordance with the constitution. The true point of the objection, in my view, is not the mode of appointing or paying the Judges, but the nature of the duties assigned to them.

“ All that it is needful to say, is, that supposing the new Court to be what I conceive it is, merely and essentially a second Supreme Court of Appeals, it would be a void tribunal, even though the Judges composing it had been elected, commissioned and paid, in accordance with the constitution. And the objection, if not aggravated, surely could not be obviated by a less regular, or to say the least, a more doubtful mode of appointment, tenure and compensation.

“ 3. The same reasoning applies to the difference in respect to the stability or permanency of the Courts themselves.

*527“ The constitutional Court must endure so long as the constitution itself shall be respected.

“ The legislative Court may be abolished by the same power which called it into being.

“ But if the latter be, in its structure and practical operation, what I suppose it — a thing forbidden — the interdict can neither be overcome nor eluded by the failure or incompetency of the Legislature to throw around it the shield of inviolability. It would be strange to hold that the constitutional Court cannot be aided or supplanted by a second complete co-ordinate Court, and yet may have its powers and jurisdiction shared or swept away by tribunals set up and pulled down at the will of the Legislature.

“ 4. Then as to the manner in which the two Courts obtain jurisdiction. Both take cognizance, as already remarked, of the same description of causes, coming from the same subordinate Courts.

“ The whole difference is, that the old Court obtains jurisdiction by direct appeal; the new one indirectly, by means of a legislative transfer.

“ But this difference, I apprehend, was not designed, nor can operate to remove the constitutional objection I have been considering, if that objection be well founded.

“ The Legislature might as constitutionally have endowed the new Court with direct, as with indirect jurisdiction.

“ But if they could not lawfully confer upon it such jurisdiction as would constitute it in reality an additional co-ordinate Court of Appeals, by a direct grant, neither could they, I humbly conceive, by an indirect one.

“ So far, the difference between the two Courts, in reference to their objects and true character, seems to be of no substantial importance — of very little more indeed than that their terms may be of unequal duration, or that they hold their sessions in different rooms of the State courthouse.

*528“ 5. The only other distinction I shall consider, is that relative to the manner in which these Courts respectively exercise their jurisdiction — the one acting ^nv^um¡ tpe other only in causes transferred to it, without objection of parties.

“I will not object, in a cavilling spirit, that to try causes where parties do not object, may be a very different thing from trying none but those which may be submitted by consent; nor on the omission to make the usual exception in favour of feme coverts, infants, &c. On the contrary, the power of the Legislature to define what shall constitute an assent, and to hold persons under disabilities equally bound as persons sui juris, is readily conceded.

“But is this a case in which consent can give jurisdiction ?

“In general, consent can give no jurisdiction.

“ Incontestibly, it can give none to a void tribunal.

“ A transfer, by consent of parties, to the Court created under the act of March 1848, has been likened to one transferring causes pending in the Court of Appeals, to inferior Courts or arbitrators for final adjudication.

“ To what extent this may or might be done, it is not material to enquire. Common law cases, I suppose, could not, under our present laws, be tried in Courts of Chancery, nor chancery causes tried before the Courts of Law. But admitting the Legislature might authorize this under their general power to regulate the jurisdiction of the Courts — still both the inferior Courts and the arbitrament in the case supposed, may be lawful tribunals. And it by no means follows, because such jurisdiction may be given to them, that any jurisdiction whatever, with or without consent, can be conferred on a tribunal which the constitution, justly expounded, absolutely prohibits.

“If the new Court be justly obnoxious to the exception before taken, it was void in its creation; and sup*529posing the Legislature, by its own intrinsic authority, incompetent to put it in operation, surely it can give it no vitality through the consent or co-operation of private individuals; not, in my humble opinion, with the acquiescence of the whole community.

“ Constitutional provisions, founded on public policy, cannot be thus abrogated. And in regard to the particular provision now under consideration, it is obvious to remark that the mischiefs, arising from the want of one supreme regulator, may occur as well where the jurisdiction is over cases tried by consent, as over those tried without it. Cases involving the same principles may be differently decided by these apparently co-ordinate Courts. The authority of the one Court will be arrayed against that of the other. The capacities of the several Judges, often perhaps invidiously scanned and compared, and the inferior Courts, as well as the community, perplexed and harassed by that very diversity of opinion the Convention designed to prevent.

“ It has been urged that the Court, created by the act of March last, is but a Special Court, so styled in the act itself, and that Special Courts have been established, without objection, both before and since the new constitution.

“ As to the title of the Court, little need be said. Its purpose, its powers, its practical operation, not its style, must determine its character. That being ascertained, no name can change its nature.

“ Passing this, the power of the Legislature to establish Special Courts will not be questioned.

“ But that power is not, I conceive, purely discretionary, nor can extend to the creation of any Court, co-ordinate in all material respects with the Supreme Court of Appeals.

“ It may be difficult in this, perhaps, as in many cases of law and morals, to define what the precise limits are. Yet some limits there must be ; and in the present case *530it may be well assumed, that if the act of March 31, 1848, find no support from any previous law or precedent, and especially if it come in conflict with the constitution, its validity cannot be maintained.

“ Admitting that Special Courts, such as were authorized at the time the constitution was framed, or even such as may have been authorized since, were strictly lawful, do they as precedents justify the Court erected under the act of March last ?

“ A brief recurrence to the legislation on this subject will shew how very cautious the General Assembly have heretofore been in providing for Special Courts, and how very jealous of supplanting or impairing the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of Appeals.

“ Up to the year 1818, the action of the Special Courts was confined to cases in which all, or a majority at least of the Court of Appeals, were interested.

“ The following year it was extended to cases where, from the combined causes of interest and disability from sickness, likely to be of long continuance, a Court could not be formed for the trial of any suit pending in the Court of Appeals.

“ And so stood the law at the period of adopting the new constitution.

“ Shortly after (March 1832,) an act was passed ‘providing for Special Courts of Appeals/ not varying materially from those just referred to. It authorizes Special Courts, whenever all or a majority of the Judges of the Court of Appeals may be interested in any cause pending in the said Court, or be disqualified by sickness or otherwise, from sitting therein.

“ Now it is true, that the Special Courts, under the acts just cited, resembled the Court of Appeals in some important particulars. The jurisdiction of the Special Courts, though exceedingly limited as to the number, was over the same description of causes. Both were attended by the same officers, and were empowered to *531enter and enforce their judgments and decrees in the same manner; and their decisions were equally final. Still there were broad lines of demarcation between the Court of Appeals and the Special Courts, which the act of March 1848, seems to have obliterated; making the Special Court thereby created, as already said, substantially an additional Supreme Court, and placing it in striking contrast with the Special Courts heretofore provided for.

“ A short summary of the particulars alluded to will illustrate this.

“ 1. The Special Courts prior to March 1848, could act only in cases where, owing to legal or physical disability, a majority at least of the Court of Appeals were actually disqualified from sitting. Under the act before ns, no one Judge is supposed to be so disqualified.

“ 2. The Court of Appeals, under the former laws, was only aided, as it were, by substituting, pro hac vice, Judges of subordinate Courts in place of those actually incapacitated. The Special Court was, by the requirement of the law, composed always of the remaining Judges of the Court of Appeals, in conjunction with the substituted Judges; though, should the former not attend, a quorum were authorized to act. It was, I think, in design and effect, one and the same Court — the original Court, with a modification adopted from necessity, to enable it to extend its jurisdiction over all cases in which a resort to that Court was allowed ; to cases otherwise without relief. The system would not have been complete, the constitution itself not satisfied, without such a modification. The Special Court merely sat in the place of the original Court, and moved, as it were, in the same orbit.

But the Special Court, under the act of March last, is a distinct Court, composed wholly of different Judges, moving in a separate and independent sphere; not only, as already said, deciding causes which no one Judge of *532the original Court may be in any way disqualified from hearing, but absolutely excluding all the original Judges, though all legally and physically qualified.

„ g jU(jges of the former Special Courts were convened but seldom, once perhaps in a twelvemonth. Being limited necessarily to few cases, they sat but a short time, and were functi officio as Judges of those Courts the moment these cases were disposed of.

,! The present Special Court, as it is styled, is a regularly organized tribunal, on the face of the act unlimited in duration, commencing its sessions on stated days, and continuing them, when not required by other judicial duties, throughout the year.

“ In lieu of a few cases, transferred for specific causes, it takes a general cognizance of a large number of causes, upon the sole ground, that they are the oldest on the docket — a number in fact, if the decisions for the last nine years be taken as a criterion, actually larger annually than can be annually decided by the Court of Appeals.

“ The necessity for Special Courts, such as heretofore existed, was obvious, and such as to render them indispensable to carry the constitution itself into full effect. They were created that the constitution should rather prevail than perish.

“ In cases of like necessity, it may be said there should exist a like remedy. Be it so. Where is the analogy between cases in which jurisdiction was given to the former Special Courts, and those in which it is exercised by that recently created? Between jurisdiction in a few specific cases, and that over a large portion of the general docket? Between cases in which the Judges of the original Court cannot act, and those where they can ? Between causes resting on the docket, because there are not Judges, for the time being, capacitated to decide them, and the speculative delays of a crowded docket? Between Courts summoned to obvi*533ate an occasional failure of all appellate jurisdiction, and Courts permanently organized to hold divided empire with the original Supreme Court, and perhaps eventually to supplant it ?

“ Delay of justice, it is said, is equal to its denial.

“ To this the answer is — 1. That such delay should be obviated by constitutional methods. 2. That delays, perhaps equal in degree, have frequently occurred, both before and since the new constitution, and were not deemed then, or at any time from the foundation of the government to the year 1848, a sufficient reason for establishing a second co-ordinate Court of Appeals.

“ The act itself is not rested on the ground of necessity, further than that necessity is involved in the fact, that causes exist on the docket of two years standing. It is worthy of remark, that the very causes assigned to the new Court, are those which should be first disposed of by the Court of Appeals; and it seems incongruous to assume any insuperable obstacle to the trial of those causes as the ground of their transfer, when the same act provides, that if there be among them any which the new Court cannot try", they shall be sent back for trial to the Court from whence they came.

“ The Legislature may have passed the law, not because they considered it a matter of necessity, but merely because they regarded it constitutional and expedient in that mode to lessen the delay of justice. And this, it is but respectful to presume, was their view.

“ If the Court, upon this ground, be constitutionally created, it may as constitutionally be continued at the pleasure of the General Assembly. If a delay of two years justify the act, so may a delay of one, or of six months.

“ The argument supposes that this necessity, if it be a good reason in itself, must be a matter of purely legislative discretion; and no period can be defined or prescribed by the judiciary or any other department, other *534than that the Legislature itself may prescribe, when, because of the decrease of the docket, the new Court, if originally constitutional, can be pronounced to be so no longer.

“ It results, that if from the aid of the new Court; the more summary action of the Court of Appeals itself ; from the dismission of appeals; the narrowing of the appellate jurisdiction, or any other cause, the docket should, as it probably will, be greatly reduced, the new Court may still be continued. Indeed it must continue, under the present law, so long perhaps as there shall be a single case of two years standing: — certainly so long as there shall be seventy such cases; and may be revived as often as such cases shall appear. More than this: The Legislature may, by an amendment as constitutional as the act itself, extend the jurisdiction of the new Court to cases of six months or one month standing, as to those of two years or more — to an equal number, or to all the cases, as to the seventy oldest. And the spectacle will then be presented of a Supreme Court of Appeals serving little or no other purpose than as a mere channel for the conveyance of causes from the subordinate Courts to the Special Court for final adjudication. In other words, that Court, which the constitution designed to be the sole and supreme regulator of our judicial system, may, by the operation of the act of March 1848, or consistently with its principles, be reduced to a secondary rank, and indeed practically superseded.

“If the act in question can be sustained, the constitutional barrier is passed. Without the violation of any principle not already violated, the new Court may be styled an additional Supreme Court of Appeals.

“The Judges, instead of being assigned by law, elected by joint vote of both houses; and have fixed salaries, in place of a per diem, allowance :

“ It may be endowed with direct instead of indirect jurisdiction:

*535“ Instead of the seventy oldest cases, may be empowered to take one half or a larger share of the docket of the original Court:

“May sit at the same times and places, or either be required to hold its sessions exclusively in Richmond, and the other in Lewisburg, disposing respectively of the eastern and western causes.

“ Such results could not spring, I humbly conceive, from constitutional legislation.

“ They demonstrate, in my opinion, the invalidity of the law and the nullity of the tribunal it has created.

“ That the Legislature designed any infraction of the constitution, none will suppose.

“ Their motives doubtless were pure, and the measure itself indeed, but for the objection to its constitutionality, may be highly beneficial.

“ But necessity and expediency lightly assumed become the ever-ready defence for all usurpation; nor is there any plea for dispensing with the fundamental law, more dangerous than the public good, — even where that is the true motive. To justify the exercise of a doubtful power, much more to excuse any measure resulting in an abrogation of the constitution, the necessity should be manifest and otherwise irremediable; or the precedents, if precedents can be pleaded, such as cover the whole ground. A constitution would be of little value with a proviso practically interpolated, dispensing with obedience to its injunctions whenever it might be deemed necessary or expedient to annul them.

“ It is not for me to dilate on the consequences to result, in case the same views, which have determined an able Judge assigned to the new Court, to decline taking his seat, should at some future day prevail in any Court of final appellate jurisdiction. That consideration properly belongs to another forum.

“I will only say, in conclusion, that desirous as I shall ever be of seconding, in my own humble sphere, *536the efforts of the General Assembly to lessen the grievous . delays or justice, I am unable to divest myself of the strong conviction, that the measure proposed by the ^ J848, runs counter to the true spirit, as we^ as ^ terms of the constitution.

“ Copies — Teste,

“ P. Roberts, Clerk.”

Upon the return of the Judge to the rule," Sharpe moved this Court for a peremptory mandamus to the Judge of the Court below; and whilst this motion was pending, the following communication was received from the Honourable John Scott:

“ To the Hon. William H. Cabell, President of the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia.

“ Sir,

“You are doubtless aware, that, acting under the conviction that an act of the General Assembly, passed at its last session, entitled ‘an act concerning the jurisdiction of the General Court, and diminishing the number of the Judges thereof,’ by which, amongst other things, certain Judges of the Circuit Courts, of which I have the honour to be one, are required to hold a (so called) Special Court of Appeals, is, so far as the proposed Court is concerned, at variance with the constitution of Virginia, I have declined to take a seat as one of its Judges; and that I-communicated the fact, and a short abstract of the grounds of my opinion, by a letter to the Speaker of the House of Delegates.

“ If my opinion be correct, the judgments of that Court are nullities, and ought not to be registered by the Circuit Courts, from which the cases were carried by appeal, to the Supreme Court, over which you preside. I am informed that Judge Robertson, concurring with me in opinion, has refused to register a judgment of the Court above mentioned, given in a case from his Court; and that an application has been made to the Supreme Court for a mandamus, to compel obedience to the Special Court.

*537“I stand in the same category with Judge Robertson, except, that my Court is not in session, and the case from it has not been decided, but is now under argument.

“As I have raised the question, and under the same circumstances should do as Judge Robertson has done, I hope I shall not be considered as intruding improperly upon your deliberations, by sending you a copy of my letter to the Speaker of the House of Delegates, and enlarging upon my objections to the act at greater length than the limits of that letter permitted. I ask leave, therefore, of the Judges of your Court, to lay before them a copy of the letter referred to, and the further views which are contained in the accompanying note,

“ The only apology which I can make for the request, and the length of the note, is the importance which I attach to the question about to be decided by the only tribunal which I recognize as having power to control my judicial opinions.

“ I am, very respectfully, yours, &c.

“ Jno. Scott.

“ Richmond, Februaty 1849.”

“ Note referred to in the Letter from J. Scott to Judge Cabell.

“At an early period of the session of the convention which framed the amended constitution of Virginia, the judicial department of the government was referred to a committee, of which the late Chief Justice Marshall was chairman. He presented to the committee, of which I had the honour to be a member, a draft of a judicial system, which, after a few alterations, was reported to the house; and will be found at page 28 of the Journal, and in Ritchie &. Cook’s Debates, page 33.

“ The entire independence of the Judges upon the Legislature, was greatly desired by the Chief Justice, and many other members of the convention, and by none more ardently than Chapman Johnson, Esq.

*538“ To attain this object, the plan of the Chief Justice provided;

“ 1. That the Judges should hold their office during good behaviour.

<<it was modified by the committee, so as to authorize their removal by a vote of two thirds of both houses, for cause assigned.

“Mr. Johnson took occasion, in committee of the whole, to express his disapprobation of this innovation. He had not been a member of the select committee. It was approved of by a decided majority of the convention, and no effort was made to strike it out.

“2. That the Judges should receive fixed má adequate salaries, which should not be diminished during their continuance in office.

“ No objection was made from any quarter to these provisions.

“ The end to be accomplished by these means was, as Mr. Johnson said: ‘Not to secure the salaries of a few men — far from it. That did not even enter into the question. “ What do we now see ? “I have objected, that the constitution designs one Supreme Court, having appellate jurisdiction only; whereas, under the law in question, there are two permanent appellate Courts, of co-ordinate authority.

“ The master mind that presided over the committee on the judiciary, framed a judicial system. Some of the leading features and principles are delineated by the express language of the constitution; others are inferential. That instrument is to be construed like all other similar instruments. Being a fundamental law, it of necessity, deals in general phrases and principles ; — much is, necessarily, left to inference. It must be construed neither strictly nor liberally, but fairly ; and that which is rationally and fairly deduced by inference, is as much a part of it as that which is declared in express terms. Looking at the judicial system as a whole, we see it arranged into different compartments. Its base, the broad foundation of the County and Corporation Courts, and the Justices of the Peace and Cor-, poration Magistrates; the shaft of the column, the Superior Courts and their Judges; the capital, the Supreme Court of Appeals and its Judges. Shall we not mar the design of the architect, if we mix the different parts ?

“ To the Supreme Court is given appellate jurisdiction only. By the terms employed in giving it a name its jurisdiction is defined; it is ‘ a Supreme Court of Appeals;’ and this attribute of supremacy was deemed so important, that the report of the committee which called it ‘ a Court of Appeals,’ was not thought to indicate it with sufficient precision; and the Convention added the word ‘ Supreme.’

“ I have heard the new Court called ‘ a branch of the Court of Appeals.’ If it is a branch, it has not proceeded from the original stock; but it is a fungus, a parasite, the seed of which had its birth in another *544place. Supreme authority cannot be branched. Supremacy implies singleness. It may, and when the powers of government are lodged in a single hand must, necessarily, in many cases, act by agents. They are not branches of the supreme authority, co-equal with it, but subordinate instruments. There cannot be two supreme authorities over the same subject in the same State. The moment you create a second with equal authority, the first ceases to be supreme, and both become co-ordinate. We have a Senate and House of Delegates. Neither is supreme, they are co-ordinate, and both together make one Legislature. It would be quite as rational to give to each supreme legislative powers, as to create two Courts of Appeal with equal authority. The constitution designed to have one body of laws, and one supreme tribunal to expound those laws, in the last resort.

“ We have in grammar three degrees of comparison— the positive, comparative and superlative. They are founded in nature. We have great, greater and greatest — which of the two Courts of Appeals is greatest ? Is not the authority of the new Court as final and conclusive as that of the old? Is there any difference in the nature or value of the controversies which they decide ? Is there any difference in their jurisdiction, except the manner in which cases find their way to their dockets. One tries the oldest, the other the younger cases. A case, to get on the docket of the new, must pass through the docket of the old Court. But the transit is not effected by the old Court. There is. certainly nothing in this which gives supremacy to the old Court.

“ Both are equally permanent. Both will continue in existence until they are abolished by a new act of legislation. This feature, whilst it assimilates the two Courts more nearly, would not, if changed, render the new Court constitutional. If the constitution requires *545but one Supreme Court, two cannot be established for a term of years, nor for an hour, but under the exigency of absolute necessity.

“ Repeal the laws which established and defined the jurisdiction of the old Court, and gave it power to grant, and hear and determine appeals, and what becomes of the Court? It is gone. The Judges remain in office, and receive their salaries, although no new duties are assigned them ; unless the Court has been abolished by a two thirds vote. Repeal the law which establishes the new Court — the Court is gone, the Judges remain in office, but their salary is taken away. This is the only difference; and this the constitution forbids.

“ It has been said that the new Court expires by a law of its nature, when its work is done. And in this way it has been assimilated to the Special Court, which, when it has tried the single cause sent to it, is functus officio. Does the constitutionality of the law depend upon the provision that no appeal is to be sent to it which is not over two years old ? If the law be in all other respects constitutional, what is there in the constitution which confines the Legislature to two years ? Why may not the limit be extended to one year, or six months ? But is it true that the Court is functus officio when there is no appeal more than two years old on the docket of the old Court ? I answer no; without fear of error. If the new Court, at its present term, disposes of every appeal that is more than two years old, it will be the duty of the clerk of the Court of Appeals, in December next, to place on the docket of the new Court every appeal on the docket of the old Court which shall be then of the proper age, so that they do not exceed seventy — there may be twice that number. It will be the duty of the Judges to attend, open their Court, and call for the docket; and if there be no cases to try, to adjourn; if there be but one cause, to try it; and this they must continue de anno in annum until *546the law is repealed. In this respect it stands on the same footing as the old Court. If that Court should sweep its docket, the Judges must assemble at the appointed time. If there are any cases they must try them; if none, adjourn; the difference being, that the Judges of the old Court would receive their 2500 dollars, and the Judges of the new Court nothing. And this is a difference which the constitution forbids. If there should be business for one Court only, and the Legislature, by less than a two thirds vote, should abolish the Court and assign the Judges no new duties, they would continue to receive their salaries, whilst the abolition of the new Court would of itself deprive the Judges of their salaries; the very state of things which so much pains were taken to prevent.

“ A larger portion of the cases carried from the Circuit Courts by appeal, for final adjudication in the Supreme Court, is assigned to the new, than to the old Court. It is calculated, as it would seem from the law, that in the hundred days during which it must sit in each year if need be, it will dispose of seventy causes. And if it goes on with the race horse speed with which it has started, which it doubtless can keep if the Judges continue to give judgments without written opinions, the calculation will be more than realized. All who are conversant with such business, know that three causes can be heard and decided in that way, for one when written, and especially seriatim opinions are delivered. There is a very strong argument in favour of seriatim opinions, in all cases of difficulty and importance. We think it necessary that a Court of supreme power, to decide finally important controversies, and authoritatively settle the law, should consist of several Judges. We tried three, and found them too few. We are content with five. To have the full benefit of numbers, all must put in requisition their talents and learning, and apply them in every case. The best, perhaps the only assurance *547which can be given that this has been done, is by seriatim opinions, which discuss the whole subject. Such is the practice of the English Courts — such has been the practice of our own Supreme Court. The pressure of business, arising in a great degree from the want of sufficient restrictions upon the right of appeal, has to some extent, innovated upon the practice.

“Open Courts of Justice, the right to be heard by counsel, and free discussion by the bar, are the strong defences which the law has erected for the protection of persons and property. The Judge must stand upon his ‘ rendered reasons.’ He thus gives proof that he has diligently and faithfully discharged his duty. They are his own best protection. Is any one willing that our Supreme Court of Appeals shall be a silent Court ? Shall its action be felt, without our knowing the why and the wherefore? How can it be known what it has adjudged the law to be, or what principles it has established, by an unexplained judgment ? With its usual three hours a day for argument, we are told that the Supreme Court has averaged less than, seventy causes a year, decided ; and it would require not less than eight years at that rate, to dispose of its present docket, to say nothing of new cases. “ Have we not then instead of one Supreme, two coordinate Courts of uncontrolled authority? Have we not surmounted the column with a double-headed monster, instead of the symmetrical capital, designed by the architect? “ I have objected, that the constitution requires Judges who are to exercise the supreme appellate power, to be elected to that office by a joint vote of the two houses *548of the General Assembly; whereas, the Judges who hold this Court, having a large share of this supreme appellate jurisdiction, have been appointed by law, from amongS(; a number of persons who have been elected an<^ commissioned as Judges of Inferior Courts; and the case of Hamper v. The case was cited, not as having decided the very question now raised, but as having settled a principle which governs that question — not as an authority in point, hut clearly analogous. It was held in that case, that the old constitution established the Courts of Common Law and Chancery, as distinct tribunals, and required Judges to be elected for each. Does not the new constitution establish the Supreme Court of Appeals and the Superior Courts, as distinct tribunals? far more distinct in their functions, than Common Law and Chancery Courts were under the old constitution. They were both Courts of original jurisdiction. The Superior Courts under the new constitution, have original jurisdiction; the Supreme Court, appellate jurisdiction only. Are not Judges required to be elected for each in almost the same words as those employed in the old constitution ? If the language of the one shall be found to be substantially the same as that of the other, and that language had received a judicial interpretation, before the new constitution was framed, shall we not give the new the same interpretation which has been given to the old ?

*549“ The constitution declares that: ‘ The judicial power shall be vested in. a Supreme Court of Appeals, in such Superior Courts as the Legislature may from time to time ordain and establish, and in the Judges thereof; in the County Courts, and in the justices of the peace. “ A distinction was taken by some members of the convention between constitutional and legislative Courts. The Court of Appeals, they said, is a constitutional Court; the Superior Courts, legislative Courts. This is referred to by high authority, as an established and existing distinction. “ It is the dvty of the Legislature to carry out the plan of the constitution, and to establish one Supreme Court of Appeals. They may or may not, at their discretion, establish Courts intermediate between it and the County Courts; but when they are established, the Judges of both are equally within the protection of the constitution. Repeal the law which defines and limits the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, and fixes the number of the Judges of which it shall be composed, and where is the existing Court of Appeals? It is abolished. Repeal them by a two thirds vote, and the Judges are out of office. They, as well as the Judges of the Superior Courts, may be turned out by a direct vote of removal. “ The constitution also declares, ‘ that the jurisdiction of these tribunals and the Judges thereof, (meaning the Supreme Court and its Judges, the Superior Court and their Judges, the County Courts and their justices, and the Corporation Courts and the magistrates who belong to the corporate body,) shall be regulated by law.’ These are sweeping words. Neither limitation, nor exception, nor modification is declared. Taken literally, and without reference to other parts of the constitution, the Legislature may turn the Courts upside down, and regulate their jurisdiction ad libitum. Are they to be taken in this large sense ? Is the power of the Legislature in this respect without limit or restriction ? Can it give original jurisdiction to the Supreme Court, and supreme appellate jurisdiction to the County Courts? And if not, where is the restriction ? The only answer to be given is, that these general words must be construed with reference to other parts of the constitution, *551and .more particularly the plan of a judicial system which it marks out. The different parts of that plan I have already pointed out. The words which give power to regulate jurisdiction, must be construed reddenda singula singulis. The plan of the constitution makes the County and Corporation Courts, Inferior Courts, puts the Superior Courts and their Judges above them, and below the Supreme Court; and the ‘Supreme Court of Appeals’ and its Judges, above all others. Legislation must conform to that plan, and preserve the lines of separation between the several parts. It is as much at variance with that plan to give the intermediate Courts, or their Judges, the supreme appellate power intended for the Supreme Appellate Court and its Judges, or any part of it, as to place the County Courts and their justices above the Superior Courts and their Judges; or to form a Court, with appellate jurisdiction over the County Courts, out of justices of the peace. “Are these words to be taken without restriction ? I have shewn that the Court of Appeals may be abolished. They will be exercising that portion of the judicial power granted to them by the Legislature, under the constitution. Depart from that system — construe the general words of the constitution which give to the Legislature the power to regulate the jurisdiction of the judicial tribunals without restriction, without reference to other parts of the constitution, without regard to the plan which indicates the stations of the several Courts, and their Judges, justices and magistrates; and there is nothing to prevent a repeal of so much of the law as requires the five senior Judges of the General Court to hold the new Court of Appeals, and substitute them by five justices of the County Courts.

“It is said that all these difficulties are removed by the consent of the parties to the causes which are removed from the old to the new Court.

“Is it a Court? Are its members Judges? Do they exercise a portion of the judicial power created by the constitution, and deposited with the tribunals there enumerated ? Or is it a board of arbitrators, deriving their *558authority from the agreement of the parties? Every word of the law shews the intention to be to establish a Court, to be held by Judges clothed with judicial power. _ . . 1 . . . If it is a Court, and its sentences are judgments, not arvards, in the technical sense of those terms, its power can only be derived from the constitution and laws passed in pursuance of it. If its members are Judges, they must be clothed with power by an election, commission, and oath of office, to hold a Court of supreme appellate jurisdiction: to hold divisum imperium with the Supreme Court. Neither parties to suits nor individuals in any character can create a Court, appoint Judges, and clothe them with judicial powers. If it has not been made a Court by a constitutional exercise of legislative power, if its members have not been appointed members of that Court in the manner prescribed by the constitution, if they are not competent to exercise as Judges the jurisdiction assigned to them, it is an unconstitutional tribunal, and there is no power in the State adequate to clothe them with that authority.

“ Is it a board of arbitrators ?

“ It is conceded that the Legislature may appoint a board of arbitrators, pay them out of the treasury, and invite suitors to submit their controversies to their arbitrament, and if they accept the invitation and enter into an agreement of submission, the arbitrators become Judges of their own choosing, and derive their authority, not from the law, but the contract of the parties. Arbitrators may be taken from among the Judges, or citizens at large; they may be men or women. But although the Legislature may pay certain individuals, to be selected by law for any designated service, large as its legislative power is, it cannot make contracts for parties. Contracts derive their validity from the assent of the parties; they consist of words, spoken or written. A silent contract, one in regard to which the parties to it have held no communication, nor uttered one word, *559orally or written, is certainly something new. Assent supposes knowledge of what is assented to. It requires parties capable of acquiring, and actually possessing, this knowledge, and capable of assenting. Does that which this law requires to be done to effect a removal of a cause from the Court of Appeals to this Court, constitute an agreement, a contract, by which the parties have consented to it ? Who are parties to the supposed contract? All who are or may be parties to a suit; married women, infants in the arms, persons non compos. Did the Legislature intend, by this left-handed operation, to repeal the laws which declare such persons incapable of binding themselves by contract; a contract by which their causes are withdrawn from the Supreme Court, held by independent and sworn Judges, to a board of arbitrators, chosen and paid by the Legislature,• or to a Court dependent on the will of the Legislature, it might be, for their bread ? The fixed salary might be necessary to keep the sheriff from their doors — a possible, though far from the actual case.

“Many, very many, suitors are scattered throughout the State. Some live in other States, and some in foreign countries. The law is published in a few hundred copies of the Sessions Acts. It makes it the duty of the clerk of the Court of Appeals, at some hour between the first day of December and the sitting of the new Court, which will generally be within the first ten days of the month, and may be the last hour of the day before the Court sits, without further notice to party or counsel, in his own chamber, if he is so minded, to take from the docket of the Court of Appeals a number of causes, not exceeding seventy, of those which are oldest, and not less than two years old, and put them on the docket of the new Court, if no objection be made by party or counsel j and when this is done the parties are said to have made a contract, by which they have agreed, one and all of them, to transfer their causes from the Supreme *560Court of Appeals to a nondescript Court (for I really am at a loss for a name to give it), or to refer their causes to arbitration ! Parties residing in distant parts of this gtate^ jQ ^g,. States, and beyond sea, many of whom never heard of the law, persons incapable of binding themselves by any other contract, are presumed, by their silence, to have made this agreement! The Legislature never could have designed, never did intend a thing, so utterly at variance with reason. It dealt with the subject as having authority to deal with it at pleasure. It gave to such parties as, from their situation and information, could avail themselves of it, an election between the two Courts; as to others, it made the election for them. It- might, if the Court be duly established, have withheld it altogether.

“It has been said that every person, without regard to condition, is presumed to know the law. There is no such rule, no such maxim. The law is not so absurd as to presume that every body knows what a great many are ignorant of, few know well, and none know perfectly. Who knows the law of any case until the Court where it is pending has pronounced judgment? Who, after a month’s.argument, knew the law of a celebrated case recently decided in this city, until the Court had pronounced judgment; who knows it even now ? The rule is not that every one knows the law, but ignorance does not excuse; ignorantia juris, non excusat. Every one is bound by the law, whether he knows it or not. Society could not otherwise exist. The rule extends only to contracts to which the parties have assented, with full knowledge of facts, fairly obtained, between parties capable of contracting, and founded on sufficient consideration; — to wrongs to the persons or property of others, and breaches of the penal laws. If this is a constitutional law it binds every one ; if not, it binds no one.

*561“ It is also said, that parties to causes in the Court of Appeals are represented by counsel. That is not always the case, and no exception is made of such a case. But waiving that consideration, it is conceded, that counsel and attorneys have power, when acting within the scope of their retainer, to bind their clients, whether they act with or without, or contrary to instructions. They may consent to the removal of a cause from one Court to another, or refer it to arbitration. But suppose this law had required the causes to be removed by the open and public act of the Court, instead of the private act of the clerk ; every practitioner knows the difference between an order which depends for its validity on the authority of the Court, and one which would be invalid but for the consent of parties. In all such cases the consent must appear. It cannot be inferred from silence. I have as much power to make contracts for others as the Legislature has. Suppose I were to publish in every newspaper in the Union, that unless objection be made before a given and distant day, I would take upon myself to act as arbitrator, and decide all, or any part, of the causes on the docket of the Court of Appeals, between parties who are adult, sui juris, and of sound mind, and placed a copy in the hands of every suitor so circumstanced, time enough for objections to be made; if none were made, would I, thereby, become arbitrator, or sole judge ? And why not ? For the very plain reason that a contract is the result of action, not inaction. You may make overtures as often, and in as many forms, as you please, but until they are accepted, they are of no avail. The party to whom they are made may receive them in silence. A contract is not a silent but a speaking thing. Would counsel be liable to an action, at the suit of his client, for having without, or contrary to, instructions, made a contract for him greatly to his prejudice, when he only remained silent when the contract was proposed to him? Would it become a contract if the party pro*562posing it should say that he should construe silence into consent? Is it not necessary, on the contrary, that the party to be bound should say or do, or omit to say or do, that which he intended should be equivalent to assent ?

“ Suppose the removal to be made by the Court, and the counsel to be asked if he consented, and answered that he was not instructed, and neither objected, nor consented, would the Court enter the order as made by consent ? And what is the difference between silence and such an answer? This law has said if he does not object, the thing shall be done. If he is silent and it be done, it is done on the authority of the law, and not on his authority ; and the question comes back, has the Legislature power to make the law ? This would be the result, if you treat the tribunal, not as a Court established, and invested with judicial powers by law, but as a board of arbitrators; and if silence would not amount to a contract to refer to arbitration, it would not make an agreement to remove a cause from one Court to another. My apology for saying so much upon this, to my mind very plain matter, is, that the supposed consent of parties is relied on in high quarters as removing all possible objections to the law. It is unnecessary to state the insurmountable difficulties which would arise, if this tribunal were considered a board of arbitrators. The Judges have not so considered themselves. They have not acted as such. Arbitrators appointed by the Legislature, and paid out of the public treasury, would hold a ‘public trust,’ the acceptance of which would vacate the commission of a Judge.

“ So far as the immediate consequences of a decision of this question, one way or the other, are concerned, it is of little practical importance. If the law shall be held to be unconstitutional, the bill reported to the House of Delegates by the committee on the judiciary, ■composed of the leading professional members of that *563body, will remove the causes to the General Court, where they will be decided by the same Judges, acting within their commission. Their judgments, in cases of sufficient importance to justify it, will be subject to revision by the Supreme Court. They will not be sufficient in number to prevent a reasonable dispatch of the business before that Court. A learned and distinguished English Judge, Lord Eldon, has said that every difficult question ought to undergo at least three discussions in different Courts. Matthews v. Warner, 4 Vesey.

“If, on the contrary, it shall be decided that a permanent Appellate Court of supreme authority can be formed by statute from amongst the Judges who have been elected and commissioned as Judges of inferior Courts, that this Court may co-exist with the Supreme Appellate Court, and hold divisum imperium, and that its Judges, instead of being permanent officers with fixed salaries, may be day labourers, for a daily stipend, depending for its continuance on the pleasure of their employers, I shall feel myself bound to yield my opinion to the authority of that tribunal which 1 admit to have power to settle finally and authoritatively, this and all other questions which come before it.

“I have raised the question, because in my humble judgment, the precedent now set, although not so intended, is calculated, and if established, may hereafter be used to prostrate the judiciary at the feet of an usurping Legislature; and because I think I see in it the overthrow of a principle which the frieuds of an independent judiciary in the convention struggled for with so much earnestness, and believed they had succeeded in establishing. A struggle in which I bore a part, though an humble one — a struggle, on the success of which depended that judicial independence which alone can give a refuge to the poor, the weak and the ignorant, from the ‘ oppressor’s wrong’ — without which the man who is marked by a dominant faction as a victim *564and a sacrifice, has no sanctuary to which he can flee for safety.”

The following communication to the Legislature from the revisors of the Code, Messrs. Robinson and Patton, ^ whom the bill creating the Special Court was prepared, was also before this Court:

“Having been instrumental in promoting the passage of the act of March 1848, and the duty being imposed upon us of revising this act, as well as all general statutes passed since the 20th of February 1846, or to be passed before the completion of the revisal, we have deemed it proper again to examine the question as to the constitutionality of the aift of March 1848, and in this examination have reviewed the legislation in respect to the Court of Appeals, under the former as well as under the amended constitution.

“ The constitution adopted for Virginia on the 29th of June 1776, provided that ‘ the two houses of Assembly shall, by joint ballot, appoint Judges of the Supreme Court of Appeals and General Court, Judges in Chancery,’ and certain others ‘to be commissioned by the governor, and continue in office during good behaviour ;’ and it further provided, that ‘ these officers shall have fixed and adequate salaries.’

“ Under this constitution, there was passed in October 1778, (9 Hen. An act afterwards passed in May 1779, (10 Hen. Stat. p. 89,) provided that the Judges of the Court of Chancery, General Court and Court of Admiralty, shall be Judges of the Court of Appeals. “ Upon the 2d of January 1788, an act passed for establishing District Courts, by the third section whereof (12 Hen. £i On consideration of this act, the Court of Appeals, at its session in April 1788, for reasons contained in a remonstrance to the General Assembly, determined not then to appoint clerks of the District Courts.

“In this remonstrance, the Judges say ‘the Court of Appeals, of whomsoever constituted, must necessarily act upon the subjects referred to all the others; and therefore the forming it, so as to consist of all the Judges, is no violation of the constitution, and that mode, assimilated to adjournments of cases before all the Judges of England in the Exchequer Chamber, may have been dictated by necessity.’ They were opposed to the act upon other grounds: upon the ground that it assigned to the Judges of the Chancery and Admiralty jurisdiction in common law cases, and to the Judges of the General Court increased duties, without a correspondent reward. 4 Call 144-5.

“ On the 22d of December 1788 a new act passed, establishing District Courts, by the fourth section whereof (12 Hen. Stat. p. 733,) it was provided, that three Judges should be elected by joint ballot of both houses of Assembly, in addition to the then nine Judges of the General Court, and that the Judges of the General *566Court should attend the District Courts. At the same time another act was passed, providing that the Court of Appeals should consist of five Judges, who should be chosen from time to time by the joint ballot of both houses of Assembly, and be commissioned by the governor. 12 Hen. Stat. 764.

“ In order to make way for the operation of the system adopted by the acts of December 1788, the Judges resigned their previous appointments (under the act of 1778,) as Judges of the Court of Appeals. The five Judges of the Court of Appeals appointed under the act of December 1788, met on the 20th of June 1789, and proceeded to business. 4 Call 150.

“ The ninth section of the act of December 1788 provided, that ‘if any one of the Judges of the Court of Appeals be interested, in any suit finally decided in the High Court of Chancery, an appeal, if prayed for, shall be to the General Court; if such Judge be interested in any suit finally decided in the General Court, such appeal shall be to the High Court of Chancery; and in either case the decision of the High Court of Chancery or General Court shall be final.’ 12 Hen. Stat. p. 765. This provision was repealed by an act of the 19th of November 1789. 18 Hen. Stat. p. 24. In lieu thereof it was then enacted, that although one or more of the Judges of the Court of Appeals be interested in any case therein, the same should be finally decided by the other Judges, if there be a number of Judges not so interested sufficient to constitute a Court. If a majority of, or* all the Judges of the Court of Appeals were interested in any case, then there was to be a Special Court constituted of the remaining Judges of the Court of Appeals, and so many of the Judges of the General Court or Court of Chancery as would make *567the number five; and if all the Judges of the Court of Appeals were interested, then no Judge of that Court was to sit, and five Judges of the General Court or Court of Chancery were to constitute the Special Court. 13 Hen. Stat. p. 25. Any such Special Court was to hear and finally decide the case, and its decision was to be enforced and executed in the same manner as if made by the Court of Appeals itself. Id. p. 26, $ 11. This act required no oath from any Judge so summoned to attend the Special Court of Appeals, but such oath was directed by the act of the 25th of October 1790. 13 Hen. Stat. p. 118-19. These acts were revised in 1792, and under the revised act, as under the original act, each Judge attending the Special Court had a per diem allowance and mileage. 13 Hen. Stat. p. 407 to 409.

“By the act of February 11, 1814, the remedy of the Special Court was extended to provide for the case of the sickness or disability of the remaining Judge or Judges of the Court of Appeals, not so disqualified. 1813-14, p. 38, ch. 12. And it being supposed that this would only embrace a case of temporary sickness or disability, by the act of 1819, the remedy was further extended to the case of a Judge, disabled by sickness or infirmity from attending the Court, when, in the opinion of the Court, such disability was likely to be of long continuance, and from the combined causes of disability and interest, the case could not otherwise be decided. 1 Rev. Code, p. 195, ch. 65.

“ The laws thus conferring powers on Special Courts of Appeals, have been repeatedly carried into execution by the Judges ; they had been so carried into execution before the convention met which formed the amended constitution; ! and may be said to have received the tacit sanction of the convention.’ It was not the object of the convention to diminish, but its purpose was to enlarge, the powers of the Legislature in respect to the *568organization of the Courts. The necessity for such enlargement had been felt since the decision in the case of Kamper v. Hawkins, 1 Va. Cas. 20. That case arose under the revised act of 1792, concerning the District (3ourts the eleventh section whereof provided that a District Court, or a Judge thereof in vacation, might exercise the same power of granting injunctions to stay proceedings on a judgment obtained in any district, that was then exercised by the Judge of the Court of Chancery ; and that the District Courts might proceed to the dissolution or final hearing of all suits commenced by injunction, under the same rules and regulations as were then prescribed by law for conducting similar suits in the Court of Chancery. 13 Hen. Stat. p. 432-3, § 11. The constitution having provided that the two houses of Assembly should, by joint ballot, appoint Judges of the General Court and Judges in Chancery, to be commissioned by the governor, it was held, in Kamper v. Hawkins, that the motion to the District Court for an injunction, should be overruled ; the Judges of the District Courts not having been appointed by ballot in the Assembly, nor commissioned by the governor as Judges in Chancery.

“In view of this decision, the convention which framed the amended constitution did not adopt as constitutional Courts the General Court or any District Court, either of law or chancery. It vested the judicial power ‘in a Supreme Court of Appeals, in such Superior Courts as the Legislature may, from time to time, ordain and establish, and the Judges thereof, in the County Courts, and justices of the peace;’ declaring that ‘ the Legislature may also vest such jurisdiction as shall be deemed necessary in Corporation Courts, and in the magistrates who may belong to the corporate body.’ And it further declared, that the jurisdiction of these tribunals, and of the Judges thereof, shall be regulated by law.

*569“ It cannot, then, he claimed, that there is in any case a constitutional right of appeal to the Supreme Court of Appeals. The jurisdiction of this, as well as of the other tribunals, being left to be regulated by law, it is entirely in the power of the Legislature to prescribe in what cases appeals may be taken to the Supreme Court of Appeals, and equally in its power to prescribe, that under certain circumstances those appeals shall be dismissed. If, therefore, the Legislature were to see that owing to the interest or sickness of the Judges of the Supreme Court, or for any other reason, causes had remained on the docket of that Court many years, and were likely to remain on it many years longer, without being decided, it would be entirely within the legislative power to provide that any appeal so remaining on the docket a number of years, (prescribed by it,) without being decided, should, at the end of that time, stand dismissed, and the decision of the Court below be deemed affirmed. While such a measure would be within the constitutional power of the Legislature, it is obviously one which ought not to be resorted to if it be practicable to provide for a fair and just decision, within a reasonable time, of all appeals allowed to the Supreme Court.

“ The act of the 31st of March 1848, makes such provision by means of Judges of the General and Circuit Courts. These Judges under the constitution have been elected Judges of the General and Circuit Courts by the joint vote of both houses of the Assembly. Before then-election, laws had been passed fixing their salaries; these salaries they accepted as adequate, and they cannot be diminished during their continuance in office. But the constitution does not prohibit an increase of the compensation of the Judges, either by an allowance of mileage, or of a per diem allowance or otherwise, if the Legislature see fit to make such increase. Hence the tenth section of the act of the 31st of March 1848, in *570no wise violates the constitution, because of its allowing each of the five Judges of the General Court, in addition to his annual salary, ten dollars per day for each day’s attendance on the General Court. It is no more a violation of the constitution to make such allowance than it would be to increase the rate of mileage which was established at the time of their election. If it be said that mileage ‘ is a compensation dependent on the continuance of the Courts, and the attendance of the Judges upon them, either of which may be discontinued by the Legislature,’ this is equally true of the per diem allowance. Were there no such per diem allowance for attendance on the General Court, the Judges would nevertheless be bound to hold the sessions of that Court; they were so bound, and did hold them before the act of March 1848; and it would indeed be remarkable if an allowance of this kind, which the Legislature was under no constitutional obligation to make, and which it has only made because it deemed it reasonable that the particular Judges who are required to hold the General Court, should have something more than the other Judges of that Court who are exempt from attending it; it would be most remarkable if such an allowance should be deemed unconstitutional. The law certainly ought not to compel, and does not compel, any Judge to receive this allowance who has any constitutional scruples about the propriety of receiving it. Yet at the same time it should not prevent other Judges from receiving it who have no such scruples. And whether received or not, those sessions of the General Court, which the Judges would be bound to hold, without any per diem allowance therefor, ought still to be held. If, as it regards the General Court, there be any unconstitutionality in the law, (which we in no wise admit,) it is obvious the objection goes no farther than to the allowance ; and the law must be executed precisely as the Judges would have to execute it, if there were no such allowance.

*571i! Then as to the Special Court of Appeals. Under the act of March 1848, the Judges of this Special Court, like the Judges of former Special Courts of Appeals, are to receive a per diem allowance for each day’s attendance.
